metadata.case_name: Labour Inspector, Central, Bombay v. Respondent

facts.text: Labour Inspector (Central), Bombay-1, appointed under Minimum Wages Act, 1948 by Central Government filed two complaints in Court of Judicial Magistrate alleging respondent contravened provisions of Minimum Wages (Central) Rules, 1950.
Respondent carrying on quarrying operation work in quarry survey Nos. 23/1, Kusegaon village near Lonavala.
Respondent failed to observe certain provisions in the Minimum Wages (Central) Rules, 1950 while carrying on quarrying operation.
Respondent submitted written statement admitting facts but contended Inspector not authorised to file complaint; only Inspector appointed by Maharashtra State competent.

Judicial Magistrate treated as preliminary objection, held word 'mine' in s.2(b)(i) of Act does not include stone quarry, appropriate Government is State Government, acquitted respondent under s.22A r/w s.18 of Act and rules.
State filed appeals before Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 779 and 780 of 1962.

Bombay High Court affirmed acquittal, held stone quarry can be 'mine' per Mines Act 1952/MMRD Act 1957 but Schedule item 8 'Employment in stone breaking and stone crushing' does not mention mine/quarry, so Central Government not appropriate.
High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the quarry operation is a 'mine' within s.2(b) of Minimum Wages Act, 1948, making Central Government the appropriate government.
Whether employment in stone breaking or stone crushing in a quarry falls within item 8 of the Schedule to the Act, attracting Central jurisdiction.
Whether Central Inspector competent to file complaints under s.22B of the Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Quarry is a mine within definition in Mines Act, 1952 s.2(j) ('any excavation... includes all open cast workings') and minerals include those obtained by quarrying; MMRD Act, 1957 adopts same definition; this meaning should be read into Minimum Wages Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Mines Act, 1952 s.2(j); MMRD Act, 1957; Minimum Wages Act s.2(b)

respondent_arguments.text: Word 'mine' in primary signification means underground excavations or workings; not sound to interpret expressions from one Act into another; meanings take colour from context.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Pandit Ram Narain v. State of UP; English decisions incl. Lord Provost... v. Farie

court_reasoning.text: Word 'mine' not definite term, susceptible of limitation/expansion per context; in s.2(b) Minimum Wages Act, context of demarcating Central/State jurisdiction and background of Govt of India Act 1935 Entries 35/36 and Mines Act 1923 shows intention to include quarries.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Otherwise incongruous if health/safety/hours in quarries by Centre but minimum wages by State.

court_reasoning.text: Item 8 'Employment in stone breaking or stone crushing' refers to quarry operations per prior SC ruling in MP Mineral Industry Assn case.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Stone normally means piece of rock, excludes manganese; refers to quarry operations.

court_reasoning.text: Reading item 8 and s.2(b) together: stone-breaking/crushing in quarry under Central jurisdiction; elsewhere State.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court wrong that item 8 excludes quarries or needs amendment.

holdings.text: 'Mine' in s.2(b) Minimum Wages Act includes quarry.
Stone-breaking/stone-crushing in quarry is scheduled employment under item 8, Central Government appropriate.
Central Inspector competent to file complaints; Magistrate/High Court erred in acquitting on incompetency ground.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pandit Ram Narain v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Not sound to interpret expressions from one Act into another; meanings from context.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lord Provost and Magistrates of Glasgow v. Farie
precedents_cited.relevance: Primary meaning of mine as underground workings, but broader views noted.

precedents_cited.case_name: Madhya Pradesh Mineral Industry Association v. Regional Labour Commissioner, Jabalpur
precedents_cited.relevance: Item 8 refers to stone-breaking/crushing as quarry operations.

statutes_cited.name: Minimum Wages Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines appropriate government; scheduled employment; penalties; cognizance by Inspector.

statutes_cited.name: Mines and Minerals (Regulation and Development) Act, 1957
statutes_cited.relevance: Adopts Mines Act 1952 definitions of mine.

statutes_cited.name: Mines Act, 1923
statutes_cited.relevance: Existing law defining mine including excavations for minerals.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Central regulation of mines/oilfields including quarries.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court holds Central Labour Inspector competent to file complaints as stone quarry is 'mine' under s.2(b) and stone-breaking/crushing therein falls under Schedule item 8; sets aside acquittal by Magistrate and High Court on ground of Inspector's incompetency.
outcome.relief_granted: Acquittal set aside; proceedings to continue.

key_quotes.text: 'Mine' means any excavation where any operation for the purpose of searching for or obtaining minerals has been or is being carried on, and includes- all open cast workings.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Adopts broad definition from Mines Act including quarries.

key_quotes.text: The word mine is not a definite term, but is one susceptible of limitation or expansion according to the intention with which it is used.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to interpreting 'mine' in context of Minimum Wages Act.

key_quotes.text: Employment in stone-breaking or stone-crushing normally we refer to stone in the sense of piece of rock and that would exclude manganese. Employment in stone-breaking or stone-crushing in this sense would refer to quarry operations.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Confirms item 8 covers quarry operations per prior precedent.
